newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft's Gates sees margins declining.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft's Gates sees margins declining.

text.p: Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates said Tuesday he expects margins to decline in the long term for the software giant.
Gates, speaking to some 2,500 Chicago executives, said the company tries to maintain a conservative outlook.
"Microsoft has a track record of trying to get analysts to be more conservative," Gates said. "The margins we enjoy probably will come down over time."
Last week, Redmond, Washington-based Microsoft reported earnings of $1.04 billion or $0.79 a share for its fiscal third quarter ended March 31, up 85 percent from $562 million or $0.44 a year ago.
The gross margin for the quarter was 90.7 percent of revenues, up from 86.6 percent in the year-earlier period.
The earnings were well above analysts' expectations, which centered on $0.64 a share. At the time, however, the company said it expected growth to slow over the next year.
"It's a business with a lot of risk, and things can change very quickly," Gates said.
He said he is coming up with creative ways to tell analysts following his company to be more conservative.
"(T)hey're not listening to us anymore," he said.
